In this way, the spiritual friend will expound the true Dharma, teach, benefit, and delight those who are vessels of the great Dharma.

Knowing that they are vessels of the great Dharma, he will then expound the profound Dharma door, namely the door of liberation of emptiness, the door of liberation of signlessness, and the door of liberation of wishlessness, non-creation, non-action, non-birth, non-arising, no-self, no person, no sentient being, and no life, and will expound the profound Dharma of dependent origination, namely that because this exists, that comes to be, namely, due to the condition of ignorance, there are volitional formations, volitional formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions clinging, clinging conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, and mental anguish. In this way, the whole mass of suffering comes to be.

Because of non-existence, there is no arising. No arising is cessation. This means that when ignorance ceases, then formations cease. When formations cease, then consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, then name-and-form ceases. When name-and-form ceases, then the six sense bases cease. When the six sense bases cease, then contact ceases. When contact ceases, then feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, then craving ceases. When craving ceases, then grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, then becoming ceases. When becoming ceases, then birth ceases. When birth ceases, then old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and distress cease. Thus, the great mass of suffering ceases.
However, in this, there is not even the slightest existent dharma that arises or ceases that can be apprehended.
Why is it so?

Because all dharmas arise from conditions. They have no master, no creator, no experiencer. They are turned by causes and conditions. Therefore, in this, there is no dharma that can be turned, nor is there no turning, nor is there turning according to conditions.
The three realms that are established are not truly arisen. They are established because of the turning of afflictions and the turning of suffering. All of them are not truly arisen.
If one observes this as it truly is, then there are no dharmas that can be made, and if there is no maker, then there is nothing made. In the ultimate truth, there is nothing to be attained at all.
Thus, it is said that there are no dharmas that can be turned, and yet there is also no non-turning.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having heard such profound dharmas, give rise to faith and understanding without doubt or regret, and enter the unimpeded wisdom-door of all dharmas.

Therefore, they do not cling to form, feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness; they do not cling to the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind; they do not cling to forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, or dharmas; they do not cling to the eye element, form element, eye-consciousness element, up to the mind element, dharma element, or mind-consciousness element. In this way, they have faith and understanding that the self-nature of all dharmas is empty.

If bodhisattvas abide in such faith and understanding, they will not diminish, they will always see the buddhas and also not diminish, they will always hear the true Dharma and also not diminish, and they will always serve the assembly.
In all their lives, they never leave seeing the Buddha, never leave hearing the Dharma, and never leave serving the pure assembly.

They encounter the appearance of buddhas in the present, and in all their lives they give rise to great diligence and diligently seek good dharmas. The diligence they give rise to is not for meaningless things.

That is to say, dwelling in a house is a meaningless thing, wives, children, relatives, the enjoyment of wealth and treasures, and male and female servants, etc. are meaningless things, and all the faults of attachment to desires and pleasures are meaningless things. They are able to abandon them and leave the household life with pure faith in the true Dharma of the buddhas.

Because of that pure mind of leaving the household life, they draw near to good friends and always do not destroy [the precepts]. Contemplating good dharmas, they attain good intentions and truly practice the good dharmas they hear.
Not attached to the excellent wisdom accomplished through words, with a deep mind they are content and delight in the Dharma without weariness, diligently seeking much learning.

As they hear the Dharma, they extensively explain it to others without attachment, not seeking fame, gain, or offerings. They explain the Dharma to others without contradicting their own words, and explain the Dharma to others as they have heard it and as they abide in it, explaining it extensively to others one by one as appropriate.
As they hear the Dharma, they give rise to great loving-kindness, not transgressing the great compassion for all sentient beings.

For the sake of much learning, they do not begrudge their bodies or lives, have few desires and are content, delight in solitary places, leave behind all confusion and noise, and are well able to support themselves.
According to the Dharma they hear, they skillfully observe the meaning, embrace the true meaning, and are not attached to the words.

According to what they embrace, they do not alone engage in their own benefit among the multitudes of gods, humans, and asuras in all worlds, but only diligently seek the unsurpassed great vehicle, benefiting and delighting all sentient beings, namely the wisdom of the Buddha, the unequaled wisdom, the supreme wisdom in the three realms, and are not negligent in what others do.
